stem: The labor and delivery nurse is reviewing the electronic fetal monitor (EFM) for four different clients. Based on the documentation in the Fetal Monitoring Summary, match each fetal heart rate (FHR) pattern to its appropriate clinical interpretation.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: G1P0 at 41 weeks. Reports decreased fetal movement. AFI is 4.0 cm (Oligohydramnios). 
Patient B: G2P1 at 39 weeks. Cervix 10 cm. Currently pushing. 
Patient C: G1P0 at 38 weeks. Noted sharp, abrupt drops in FHR during contractions. 
Patient D: G1P0 at 40 weeks. Maternal fever of 101.8Â°F; foul-smelling amniotic fluid noted.

tabs.title: Fetal Monitoring Summary
tabs.content:
PatientPattern DescriptionBaselineVariability
ALate decelerations; return to baseline after contraction130Minimal
BEarly decelerations; mirror the contractions145Moderate
CVariable decelerations; V-shaped drops140Moderate
DTachycardia; persistent FHR > 165170Minimal

tabs.title: Clinical Background
tabs.content: Patient D: WBC 18,000 (Elevated), indicating suspected Chorioamnionitis.

rows.text: Pattern occurs after the peak and returns late (Placental Insufficiency)

rationale.correct: Early decelerations (r1) mirror the contraction and are benign head compressions (c1). Late decelerations (r2) indicate uteroplacental insufficiency (c2). Variables (r3) indicate cord compression (c3). Fetal tachycardia (r4) is often the first sign of maternal infection or chorioamnionitis (c4).
clinicalPearls: Fetal tachycardia (>160) is the earliest sign of chorioamnionitis.
Variable decelerations require maternal position change.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a heart rate of 155 is 'tachycardia'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Normal FHR is 110-160. Tachycardia is only > 160.
